рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рддреНрд░рд┐рднрд┐рдГ рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХреИрдГ рд╕реБрд╡рд░реНрдгрд╕реНрддреЗрдпрдкреНрд░рд╛рдпрд╢реНрдЪрд┐рддреНрддрд╡рд┐рдзрд┐рдГ ред рдХреНрд╖рддреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рджреАрдирд╛рдВ рдЪ рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖реЗрдг рдкреНрд░рд╛рдпрд╢реНрдЪрд┐рддреНрддрд╡рд┐рдзреЗрд░реН рдЕрдирд╛рдореНрдирд╛рддрддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН рд╕реБрд╡рд░реНрдгрд╕реНрддреЗрдпрдХреГрджреН рд╡рд┐рдкреНрд░ рдЗрддрд┐ рдпрджреН рдЗрджрдВ рд╡рд┐рдкреНрд░рдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрдореН рдПрддрддреН рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╡рд░реНрдгрдкреНрд░рджрд░реНрд╢рдирд╛рд░реНрдердВ рд╡рд┐рдЬреНрдЮреЗрдпрдореН ред рддрдерд╛ “рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрд╕реН рддрдкрд╕реИрд╡ рд╡рд╛” рдЗрддрд┐ рдпрджреН рдЙрдХреНрддрдореН рдЕрддреНрд░реЗрджрдореН рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ ред рди рд╣рд┐ рддрдкрд╢реН рд╢рдХреНрдпрддреЗ рдХреНрд╖рддреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рджрд┐рд╡рд░реНрдгрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реЗрджреНрдзреБрдореН ред рдЕрдкрд░реЗ рддреНрд╡реН рдПрддрд╕реНрдорд╛рджреН рдпрддреНрдирд╛рддреН рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдЗрд╡реИрдХрд╕реНрдп рддрдкрдГ рдиреЗрддрд░реЗрд╖рд╛рдВ рд╡рд░реНрдгрд╛рдирд╛рдореН рдЗрддрд┐ рдордиреНрдпрдиреНрддреЗ ред рд░рд╛рдЬрд╛рднрд┐рдЧрдордирд╕реНрдп рдЪ рд░рд╛рдЬрдзрд░реНрдореЗрд╖реБ рд╕рд┐рджреНрдзрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдкрд┐ рд╕рддрдГ рдкреБрдирд░реН рдЗрд╣реЛрдкрджреЗрд╢рдГ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдпрд╢реНрдЪрд┐рддреНрддрд╛рд░реНрдердГ, рддрддреНрд░ рдЪ рд░рд╛рдЬрджрдгреНрдбрд╛рд░реНрдердГ, рддрдкреЛрд╡рд┐рдзрд┐рддреНрд╕рдпрд╛ рд╡рд╛ рдкреБрдирд░реНрдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрдореН ред рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрд╕реНрдп рдЪ рд╡рдзреЛ рдирд╛рд╕реНрддреАрддрд┐ рддрддреНрд░реИрд╡реЛрдХреНрддрдореН ред рдирд┐рдЧрджрд╡реНрдпрд╛рдЦреНрдпрд╛рддрдореН рдЕрдиреНрдпрддреН рее резрез.репреотАУрезрежреж рее

B├╝hler

102 He who desires to remove by austerities the guilt of stealing the gold (of a Brahmana), shall perform the penance (prescribed) for the slayer of a Brahmana, (living) in a forest and dressed in (garments) made of bark.

102 рдПрддреИрд░реН рд╡реНрд░рддреИрд░реН ...{Loading}...

рдПрддреИрд░реН рд╡реНрд░рддреИрд░реН рдЕрдкреЛрд╣реЗрдд
рдкрд╛рдкрдВ рд╕реНрддреЗрдпрдХреГрддрдВ рджреНрд╡рд┐рдЬрдГ ред
рдЧреБрд░реБрд╕реНрддреНрд░реАрдЧрдордиреАрдпрдВ рддреБ
рд╡реНрд░рддреИрд░реН рдПрднрд┐рд░реН рдЕрдкрд╛рдиреБрджреЗрддреН рее резрез.резрежреи рее [резрежрез рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдкрд╛рдареЗ]

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The twice-born man shall remove the guilt caused by theft by means of these penances. That caused by intercourse with the PreceptorтАЩs wife he shall wipe off by means of these following penances.тАФ(102)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ рдирдиреБ рдЪ "рд╡рдзреЗрди рд╢реБрдзреНрдпрддрд┐ рд╕реНрддреЗрдирд╕реН рддрдкрд╕рд╛ рдЪ" (рдореНрдзреН резрез.резрежреж) рдЗрддрд┐ рджреНрд╡рдпрд╕реНрдп рдкреНрд░рд╛рдХреНрддрдирддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН, **рдПрддреИрд░реН** рдЗрддрд┐ рдмрд╣реБрд╡рдЪрдирдВ рди рд╕рдореНрдпрдХреН ред

  • рдПрддрджреН рдПрд╡ рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдкрдХрдореН- рдПрд╖ рдирд┐рдГрд╢реЗрд╖реЛрдХреНрддрд╛рдиреН рдЕрдкреНрдпреН рдЕрдиреБрдХреНрддрд╛рдгреН рдХрд▓реНрдкреЗрддрд╛рдиреБрдмрдиреНрдзрд╛рджреНрдпрдкреЗрдХреНрд╖рдпрд╛ ред

  • рдЧреБрд░реБрд╕реНрддреНрд░реАрдЧрдордирдкреНрд░рдпреЛрдЬрдирдВ рдЧреБрд░реБрд╕реНрддреНрд░реАрдЧрдордиреАрдпрдореН ред рдирд┐рдорд┐рддреНрддрдореН рдЕрдкрд┐ рдкреНрд░рдпреЛрдЬрдирдореН рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ, рдкреНрд░рдпреЛрдЬрдпрддрд┐ рдкреНрд░рд╡рд░реНрддрдпрддреАрддрд┐ рее резрез.резрежреи рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАЬInasmuch as only two modes of purification have been mentioned aboveтАФтАШthe thief becomes purified by death, and also by penance,тАЩтАФthe plural number in тАШthese penances,тАЩ does not appear to be rightтАЭ

This same use of the plural number is indicative of the fact that there are other expiations also, which have not been mentioned,тАФto be determined by the considerations of the circumstances attending each case.

тАШGurustr─лgaman─лyamтАЩ means that of which intercourse with the PreceptorsтАЩs wife is the incentive;тАФthe cause is often regarded as the prayojana, the incentive, which prompts or brings about the effectтАФ(102)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 11.99-102)
**

[[See above 8.314-316.]]

See Comparative notes for [Verse 11.99].

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдЙрдкрд╕рдВрд╣рд╛рд░реЛрдкрдиреНрдпрд╛рд╕рдГ рдкреВрд░реНрд╡реЛрддреНрддрд░рдкреНрд░рдХрд░рдгрдпреЛрдГ рее резрез.резрежрез рее

B├╝hler

103 By these penances a twice-born man may remove the guilt incurred by a theft (of gold); but he may atone for connexion with a Guru’s wife by the following penances.

103 рдЧреБрд░реБрддрд▓реНрдкреНрдпреН рдЕрднрд┐рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпреИрдирд╕реН ...{Loading}...

рдЧреБрд░реБрддрд▓реНрдкреНрдпреН рдЕрднрд┐рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпреИрдирд╕реН
рддрдкреНрддреЗ рд╕реНрд╡рдкреНрдпрд╛рджреН рдЕрдпреЛрдордпреЗ [рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдкрд╛рдардГ - рддрд▓реНрдкреЗ рд╕реНрд╡рдкреНрдпрд╛рджреН] ред
рд╕реВрд░реНрдореАрдВ рдЬреНрд╡рд▓рдиреНрддреАрдВ рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рд╢реНрд▓рд┐рд╖реНрдпреЗрдиреН
рдореГрддреНрдпреБрдирд╛ рд╕ рд╡рд┐рд╢реБрдзреНрдпрддрд┐ [рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдкрд╛рдардГ - рд╡рд╛рд╢реНрд▓рд┐рд╖реНрдпреЗрдиреН] рее резрез.резрежрей рее [резрежреи рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдкрд╛рдареЗ]

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

He who has violated his PreceptorтАЩs bed shall confess his crime and lie down upon a heated iron-bed; or embrace a blazing image. By death he becomes purified.тАФ(103)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдЧреБрд░реБрддрд▓реНрдкрдЧрдГ ред “рдЧреБрд░реБрддрд▓реНрдкреА” рдЗрддрд┐ рд╡рд╛ рдкрд╛рдардГ ред рддрд▓реНрдкреАрддрд┐ рдорддреНрд╡рд░реНрдереАрдпреЗрди рд╡рд┐рд╢рд┐рд╖реНрдЯ рдПрд╡ рд╕реНрддреНрд░реАрдкреБрдВрд╕рдпреЛрдГ рд╕рдВрд╕рд░реНрдЧ рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ ред рдЧреБрд░реБрд░реН рдЖрдЪрд╛рд░реНрдпрдГ рдкрд┐рддрд╛ рдЪреЗрддрд┐ ред рддрд▓реНрдкрд╢рдмреНрджреЛ рджрд╛рд░рд╡рдЪрдирдГ ред рдЖрдЪрд╛рд░реНрдпрд╛рдгреА рдЧрддреНрд╡реЗрджрдВ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдпрд╢реНрдЪрд┐рддреНрддрдореН ред рдЕрдкрд░рд╛ рдорд╛рддреЗрд╡ рдорд╛рддрд╛рд╕рдорд╛рдирдЬрд╛рддреАрдпрд╛рдпрд╛рдВ рдЧрдордиреЗ136 ред рдЗрдорд╛рдирд┐ рддреНрд░реАрдгрд┐ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдпрд╢реНрдЪрд┐рддреНрддрд╛рдирд┐ рдХрд▓реНрдкреНрдпрддреЗ137 рдмреБрджреНрдзрд┐рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рдВ рдЪ ред рдЕрднрд┐рднрд╛рд╖реИрдирдГ рдкрд╛рдкрдВ рд╡рд┐рдЦреНрдпрд╛рдкреНрдп ред рддрд▓реНрдкреЗ138 рд╢рдпрдиреЗ рд╜рдЧреНрдирд┐рд╕реНрдкрд░реНрд╢реЗ рд╜рдпреЛрдордпреЗ рд╢рдпреАрдд, рдореГрддреНрдпреБрдирд╛ рд╢реБрдзреНрдпрддреАрддрд┐ рд╡рдЪрдирд╛рддреН ред рд╕реВрд░реНрдорд┐рдГ139 рддрдкреНрддрд╛ рд╕реНрддреНрд░реАрдкреНрд░рдХреГрддрд┐рд░реН рдЕрдпреЛрдордпреА, рддрд╛рдореН рдЖрд╢реНрд▓рд┐рд╖реНрдпреЗрджреН рдЖрд▓рд┐рдЩреНрдЧреНрдпреЗрддреН рее резрез.резрежрей рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШHe who has violated his preceptorтАЩs bedтАЩтАФAnother reading his тАШGurutalp─лтАЩ;тАФthe term тАШtalp─лтАЩ ending in the possessive affix, stands for a particular form of intercourse between man and woman.

By тАШpreceptor,тАЩ here is meant the Preceptor as well as the Father. And тАШbedтАЩ stands for the wife.

The expiation here laid down is for intercourse with the wife of oneтАЩs preceptor, or with a step-mother of the same caste; and the three expiations here set forth refer to a case where the act has been intentional.

тАШConfess his guiltтАЩтАФ proclaim his crime.

He shall lie down upon a bed of iron as hot as fire; that this is what is meant is dear by the next sentenceтАФтАШHe becomes purified by death.тАЩ

тАШS┼лrmiтАЩ is image of a woman, made of iron. This he shall embrace.тАФ(103)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Apar─Бrka, (p. 1083), which adds the following notes:тАФThe culprit should openly proclaim his offence of having violated his GuruтАЩs bed;тАФтАШs┼лrm─лтАЩ is a female image made of iron or some such metal.

It is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Pr─Бya┼Ыcitta, p. 255);тАФin Madanap─Бrij─Бta (p. 836 and 837), which notes that there are two expiations prescribed here:тАФ(a) lying down upon a heated iron-bed, and (b) embracing the red hot image;тАФin Nс╣Ыsiс╣Гhapras─Бda (Pr─Бya┼Ыcitta 11 a);тАФand in Pr─Бya┼Ыcittaviveka (p. 137), which explains тАШgurutalpaс╕етАЩ (which is its reading for тАШgurutalp─лтАЩ) as тАШguroс╕е talpam talpam yasya,тАЩ тАШs┼лrm─лтАЩ as an iron image.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 11.103-107)
**

Gautama (23.8-11).тАФтАШHe who has defiled his GuruтАЩs bed shall lay himself down on a heated iron-bed; or he shall embrace the red-hot iron-image of a woman; or he shall tear out his organ and testicles and, holding them in his hands, walk straight towards the south-west, until he falls down dead. He will be purified after death.тАЩ

Baudh─Бyana (2.1.13-15).тАФтАШHe who has defiled his GuruтАЩs bed shall lay himself down on a heated iron bed;тАФor embrace the red-hot image of a woman;тАФor cutting off his organ together with the testicles, and holding them in his joined hands, he shall walk towards the south-west until he falls down dead.тАЩ

─Аpastamba (1.25.1-2).тАФтАШHe who has had connection with his GuruтАЩs wife shall cut off his organ together with the testicles, take them in his joined hands and walk towards the south until he falls down dead. Or he may die embracing a heated metal-image of a woman.тАЩ

Va┼Ыiс╣гс╣нha (22.13-14).тАФтАШHe who violates his GuruтАЩs bed shall, cut off his organ together with the testicles, take them in his joined hands and walk towards the south; whenever he meets with an obstacle, there he shall stand until he dies;тАФor having shaved all his hair and smeared his body with clarified butter, he shall embrace the heated iron-image of a woman. It is declared in the Veda that he is purified after death.тАЩ

Viс╣гс╣Зu (34.1, 2;тАФ53.1).тАФтАШSexual connection with oneтАЩs mother or daughter or daughter-in-law is crime of the highest degree. Such criminals of the highest degree should enter the flames; there is no other way to atone for the crime. One who has had illicit sexual intercourse must perform the Pr─Бj─Бpatya penance for one year according to the rule of the Mah─Бvrata.тАЩ (P. 839)

Mah─Бbh─Бrata (12.165.50-51).тАФ(Same as Manu.)

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (3.259-260).тАФтАШThe violator of his GuruтАЩs bed should he down on a heated iron-bed along with the iron-image of a woman; or cutting out his testicles and holding them he shall give up his body towards the south; or he shall perform the Pr─Бj─Бpatya penance for one year, or the C─Бndr─Бyaс╣Зa for three months, and shall repeat the Vedic text.тАЩ

B├╝hler

104 He who has violated his Guru’s bed, shall, after confessing his crime, extend himself on a heated iron bed, or embrace the red-hot image (of a woman); by dying he becomes pure;

104 рд╕реНрд╡рдпрдВ рд╡рд╛ ...{Loading}...

рд╕реНрд╡рдпрдВ рд╡рд╛ рд╢рд┐рд╖реНрдг-рд╡реГрд╖рдгрд╛рд╡реН
рдЙрддреНрдХреГрддреНрдпрд╛рдзрд╛рдп рдЪрд╛рд╜рдЮреНрдЬрд▓реМ ред
рдиреИрд░реГрддреАрдВ рджрд┐рд╢рдореН рдЖрддрд┐рд╖реНрдареЗрджреН
рдЖ рдирд┐рдкрд╛рддрд╛рджреН рдЕрдЬрд┐рд╣реНрдордЧрдГ рее резрез.резрежрек рее [резрежрей рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдкрд╛рдареЗ]

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

Or, having cut off his penis and testicles, he shall take them in his joined hands and walk straight on towards the тАШregion of evil spirits,тАЩ until he falls down.тАФ(104)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдЙрддреНрдХрд░реНрддрдиреЗрди140 рдХрд▓реНрдкреЗрди рд╢реЛрдзрдирдореН ред рд╢рд╕реНрддреНрд░рд╛рдзреНрдпрд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдкреНрддрд╢рдХреНрддрд┐рдГ141 рд╕рд░реНрд╡рддреНрд░ рд╕рд╣рдХрд╛рд░рд┐рдгреА ред рдпреЗрди рд╢рдХреНрдпреЗрдд рдЫреЗрддреНрддреБрдВ рддрддреНрд╕рд╛рдорд░реНрдереНрдпрд╛рд▓реН рд▓рднреНрдпрддреЗ ред рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрдЧреНрджрдХреНрд╖рд┐рдгрд╛142 рдиреИрд░реГрддреА рджрд┐рдХреН ред рдЕрдЬрд┐рд╣реНрдордЧреЛ рд╜рдХреБрдЯрд┐рд▓рдЧрдГ ред рд╢реНрд╡рднреНрд░рдХреВрдкрд╛рджрд┐ рди рдкрд░рд┐рд╣рд░реЗрджреН рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрд░реНрдердГ ред рдХреБрдбреНрдпрд╛рджрд┐рд╖реБ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдпрд╛рддрдирдВ143 рд╣рд┐ рддрджрд╛рдкрд╛рддрд╛рджреН рдЧрдЪреНрдЫреЗрджреН рдПрд╡ рее резрез.резрежрек рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The тАШcutting offтАЩ here mentioned is conducive to purification. The use of a cutting instrument is implied by the fact that every act needs the requisite implements; so that the weapon implied must be one that is fit to be used for the required cutting.

The South-west is the тАШregion of evil spirits.тАЩ

тАШStraight on,тАЩтАФnot deviating from the straight line; so that he may not seek to avoid wells or pits and such things; but in the case of walls and such obstacles, he should certainly go round them.тАФ(104)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (3.259), which offers the following explanation:тАФHe should himself cut off his testicles and the organ, take them in his hands and go away straight onwards towards the South-West, till his body falls off; it adds that the man should go towards the South-West backwards and with eyes bandaged.

It is quoted in Madanap─Бrij─Бta (p. 836), which also adds that the man should go backwards and with eyes closed;тАФin Apar─Бrka (p. 1083);тАФin Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Pr─Бya┼Ыcitta, p. 253);тАФin Nс╣Ыsiс╣Гhapras─Бda (Pr─Бya┼Ыcitta, p. 11a);тАФand in Pr─Бya┼Ыcittaviveka (p. 137), which says that the тАШcuttingтАЩ should be done with a razor as distinctly prescribed by ┼Ъaс╣Еkha-Likhita.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 11.103-107)
**

See Comparative notes for [Verse 11.103].

B├╝hler

105 Or, having himself cut off his organ and his testicles and having taken them in his joined hands, he may walk straight towards the region of Nirriti (the south-west), until he falls down (dead);

105 рдЦрдЯреНрд╡рд╛рдЩреНрдЧреА рдЪреАрд░-рд╡рд╛рд╕рд╛ ...{Loading}...

рдЦрдЯреНрд╡рд╛рдЩреНрдЧреА рдЪреАрд░-рд╡рд╛рд╕рд╛ рд╡рд╛
рд╢реНрдорд╢реНрд░реБрд▓реЛ рд╡рд┐рдЬрдиреЗ рд╡рдиреЗ ред
рдкреНрд░рд╛рдЬрд╛рдкрддреНрдпрдВ рдЪрд░реЗрддреН рдХреГрдЪреНрдЫреНрд░рдореН
рдЕрдмреНрджрдореН рдПрдХрдВ рд╕рдорд╛рд╣рд┐рддрдГ рее резрез.резрежрел рее [резрежрек рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдкрд╛рдареЗ]

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

Or, carrying a bedstead, clothed in rags, with beard grown, he shall perform, in the solitary forest, the тАШPr─Бj─БpatyaтАЩ penance, for one year, with concentrated mind.тАФ(105)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдЕрдмреБрджреНрдзрд┐рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рдХрдВ рд╕реНрд╡рднрд╛рд░реНрдпрд╛рднреНрд░рд╛рдиреНрддреНрдпрд╛144 рдЧрдорди рдЗрджрдВ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдпрд╢реНрдЪрд┐рддреНрддрдореН ред рд╡рд┐рдЬрд╛рддреАрдпрдЧрдордиреЗ145 рдмреБрджреНрдзрд┐рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рдХрдореН рдЕрдкрд┐ ред рдЪреАрд░рдВ рд╡рд╕реНрддреНрд░рдЦрдгреНрдбрдореН ред рд╢реНрдорд╢реНрд░реБрд▓реЛ рд░реВрдврд╢реНрдорд╢реНрд░реБрдГ ред рд╕рдорд╛рдирдЬрд╛рддреАрдпрд╛рдпрд╛ рдЕрдкрд┐ рд╡реНрдпрднрд┐рдЪрд╛рд░рд┐рдгреНрдпрд╛ рдЧрдордиреЗ рд▓рдШреНрд╡реН рдПрд╡ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдпрд╢реНрдЪрд┐рддреНрддрдореН146 рее резрез.резрежрел рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

This expiation refers to a case where the crime has been committed unintentionally, under the misapprehension that the woman was the manтАЩs own wife;тАФor when the crime is intentional, and the woman belongs to a different caste.

тАШRags,тАЩ тАШc─лra,тАЩтАФpieces of doth.

тАШWith beard grownтАЩтАФletting his beard grow.

Even in a case where the woman is of the same caste, if she is an unchaste woman, the expiation shall be a light one.тАФ(105)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

This verse is quoted in Madanap─Бrij─Бta (p. 840);тАФand in Pr─Бya┼Ыcittaviveka (p. 140), which says that this refers to unintentional intercourse with the guru-patn─л who is unchaste.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 11.103-107)
**

See Comparative notes for [Verse 11.103].

B├╝hler

106 Or, carrying the foot of a bedstead, dressed in (garments of) bark and allowing his beard to grow, he may, with a concentrated mind, perform during a whole year the Krikkhra (or hard, penance), revealed by Pragapati, in a lonely forest;

106 рдЪрд╛рдиреНрджреНрд░рд╛рдпрдгрдВ рд╡рд╛ ...{Loading}...

рдЪрд╛рдиреНрджреНрд░рд╛рдпрдгрдВ рд╡рд╛ рддреНрд░реАрдиреН рдорд╛рд╕рд╛рдиреН
рдЕрднреНрдпрд╕реНрдпреЗрдиреН рдирд┐рдпрддреЗрдиреНрджреНрд░рд┐рдпрдГ ред
рд╣рд╡рд┐рд╖реНрдпреЗрдг рдпрд╡рд╛рдЧреНрд╡рд╛ рд╡рд╛
рдЧреБрд░реБрддрд▓реНрдкрд╛рдкрдиреБрддреНрддрдпреЗ рее резрез.резрежрем рее [резрежрел рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдкрд╛рдареЗ]

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

Or, with his senses controlled, he shall perform the тАШC─Бndr─Бyaс╣ЗaтАЩ for three months, subsisting on тАШsacrificial foodтАЩ or on barley-gruel,тАФfor the expiating of the sin of violating the PreceptorтАЩs bed.тАФ(106)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдЕрддрд┐рджрд┐рд╖реНрдЯрдЧреБрд░реБрднрд╛рд╡рд╛рдирд╛рдВ рдорд╛рддреБрд▓рдкрд┐рддреГрд╡реНрдпрд╛рджреАрдирд╛рдВ рдпрд╛ рднрд╛рд░реНрдпрд╛рд╕реН рддрджреНрдЧрдорди рдЗрджрдВ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдпрд╢реНрдЪрд┐рддреНрддрдореН ред рд╣рд╡рд┐рд╖реНрдпрдВ рдкрдпреЛрдореВрд▓рдШреГрддрд╛рджрд┐ ред рдпрд╡рд╛рдЧреВ рджреНрд░рд╡рдкреЗрдпрд╛рджрд┐ рее резрез.резрежрем рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

This expiation refers to those cases where the woman happens to be the wife of the maternal uncle or such other persons as are generally treated as тАШguru,тАЩ тАШpreceptor.тАЩ

тАШSacrificial foodтАЩтАФmilk, roots, butter and so forth.

тАШBarley-gruelтАЩтАФa particular kind of drink.тАФ(106)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 11.103-107)
**

See Comparative notes for [Verse 11.103].

рднрд╛рд░реБрдЪрд┐рдГ

рдЪрддреБрд░реНрднрд┐рдГ рд╢реНрд▓реЛрдХреИрдГ рдЧреБрд░реБрддрд▓реНрдкрдкреНрд░рд╛рдпрд╢реНрдЪрд┐рддреНрддрдореН рдЗрджрдВ рд╡реИрдХреГрддрд┐рдХрдореН ред рдЧреБрд░реБрд░реН рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдЦреНрдпрд╛рддреЛ рд╡рд┐рджреНрдпрд╛рдЧреБрд░реБрдГ рд╕реНрд╡рдпреЛрдирд┐рдЧреБрд░реБрд╢реН рдЪ ред рддрджрдЩреНрдЧрдирд╛рдВ рдЧрддреЛ рдЧреБрд░реБрддрд▓реНрдкрдЧ рдЗрддрд┐ рдЧреБрдгрддрд╕реН рддрд▓реНрдкрд╢рдмреНрджреЛ рдЧреБрд░реБрднрд╛рд░реНрдпрд╛рдпрд╛рдВ рд╡рд┐рдЬреНрдЮреЗрдпрдГ ред рд╣рд╡рд┐рд╖реНрдпрдпрд╡рд╛рдЧреНрд╡реЛрд╢реН рдЪ рдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрдВ рдЧреЛрдмрд▓реАрд╡рд░реНрджрдиреНрдпрд╛рдпреЗрди ред рдЛрдЬреНрд╡реН рдЕрдиреНрдпрддреН рее резрез.резрежреитАУрезрежрел рее

B├╝hler

107 Or, controlling his organs, he may during three months continuously perform the lunar penance, (subsisting) on sacrificial food or barley-gruel, in order to remove (the guilt of) violating a Guru’s bed.

107 рдПрддреИрд░реН рд╡реНрд░рддреИрд░реН ...{Loading}...

рдПрддреИрд░реН рд╡реНрд░рддреИрд░реН рдЕрдкреЛрд╣реЗрдпреБрд░реН
рдорд╣рд╛рдкрд╛рддрдХрд┐рдиреЛ рдорд▓рдореН ред
рдЙрдкрдкрд╛рддрдХрд┐рдирд╕реН рддреНрд╡реН рдПрд╡рдореН
рдПрднрд┐рд░реН рдирд╛рдирд╛рд╡рд┐рдзреИрд░реН рд╡реНрд░рддреИрдГ рее резрез.резрежрен рее [резрежрем рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдкрд╛рдареЗ]

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

By means of these penances, the committers of heinous crimes may wipe off their sins. The committers of minor offences may do the same by their following the several forms of penances.тАФ(107)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдЙрдХреНрддрд╡рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрдорд╛рдгрд╕рдВрдХреНрд╖реЗрдкрд╡рдЪрдиреЛ рд╜рдпрдореН рее резрез.резрежрен рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

This summarises what has been said before and what is going to be said nextтАФ(107)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 11.103-107)
**

See Comparative notes for [Verse 11.103].

B├╝hler

108 By means of these penances men who have committed mortal sins (Mahapataka) may remove their guilt, but those who committed minor offences, causing loss of caste, (Upapataka, can do it) by the various following penances.

108 рдЙрдкрдкрд╛рддрдХрд╕рдВрдпреБрдХреНрддреЛ рдЧреЛрдШреНрдиреЛ ...{Loading}...

рдЙрдкрдкрд╛рддрдХрд╕рдВрдпреБрдХреНрддреЛ
рдЧреЛрдШреНрдиреЛ рдорд╛рд╕рдВ рдпрд╡рд╛рдиреН рдкрд┐рдмреЗрддреН ред
рдХреГрдд-рд╡рд╛рдкреЛ рд╡рд╕реЗрджреН рдЧреЛрд╖реНрдареЗ
рдЪрд░реНрдордгрд╛ рддреЗрди рд╕рдВрд╡реГрддрдГ рее резрез.резрежрео рее [резрежрен рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдкрд╛рдареЗ]

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The cow-killer, charged with a minor offence, shall drink barley for three months; and having shaved his head and covered with the skin of the cow, he shall live in the cow-pen.тАФ(108)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдЧреЛрдШреНрдиреЛ рдЧреЛрдШрд╛рддреА, “рдореВрд▓рд╡рд┐рднреБрдЬрд╛рджрд┐рджрд░реНрд╢рдирд╛рддреН рдХрдГ” (рдХрд╛рддреН реи рдУрдиреН рдкрд╛рдгреН рей.реи.рел) ред

  • рдпрд╡рд╛рдиреН рдкрд┐рдмреЗрджреН рдЗрддрд┐ рдпрд╡рд╕рдХреНрддреБрдкрд╛рдирдВ рдХреЗрдЪрд┐рджреН рдЖрд╣реБрдГ ред

  • рдЕрдиреНрдпреЗ рддреБ рдкреНрд░рдХреГрддрд┐рд╢рдмреНрджрдГ рдХрд╛рд░реНрдпреЗ147 рдпрд╡рд╛рдЧреНрд╡рд╛рдВ рдкреНрд░рдпреБрдХреНрддреЛ рд╜рддреЛ рдпрд╡рд╛рдиреН рдкрд┐рд╖реНрдЯреНрд╡рд╛ рдкрд╛рдпрдпреЗрджреН рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЙрдХреНрддрдВ рднрд╡рддрд┐ ред

  • рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рд╕реНрдорд┐рдиреН рдкрдХреНрд╖реЗ рд╜рд╢реНрд░реБрддреЛрджрдХрд╛рджрд┐рджреНрд░рд╡рдХрд▓реНрдкрдирд╛ рднрд╡рддрд┐ ред рди рд╣рд┐ рдпрд╡рд╛ рдЙрджрдХрд╛рджрд┐рдирд╛ рд╡рд┐рдирд╛ рдкрд╛рддреБрдВ рд╢рдХреНрдпрдиреНрддреЗ ред рдЗрд╣ рддреБ рд▓рдХреНрд╖рдгрдорд╛рддреНрд░рдореН, рдЕрд╢реНрд░реБрддрдХрд▓реНрдкрдирд╛рдпрд╛рд╢реН рдЪ рд▓рдШреНрд╡реА рд▓рдХреНрд╖рдгрд╛ ред

  • рдХреГрддрд╡рдкрдирдГ рдХреГрддрдореМрдгреНрдбреНрдпрдГ, рдХреЗрд╢рдЪреНрдЫреЗрджрд╡рдЪрдиреЛ рд╡рд╛ ред рдЧреЛрд╖реНрдареЗ рдпрддреНрд░ рдЧрд╛рд╡ рдЖрд╕рддреЗ ред рдЪрд░реНрдордгрд╛ рддреЗрди ред рдпрд╛ рди148 рдЧреМрд░реН рд╣рддрд╛, рдЕрдкрд┐ рддреНрд╡реН рдЕрдиреНрдпрд╕реНрдпрд╛ рдЕрдкрд┐ рее резрез.резрежрео рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШCow-killerтАЩтАФone who has killed a cow; the word being formed with the тАШKaтАЩ affix.

тАШShall drink barley.тАЩтАФSome people explain this to mean a drink mixed with barley. Others, however, hold that the name of the original substance (barley) has been used in the sense of its product; hence what is meant is that the man shall drink barley-gruel.

In the ease of the former explanation, it is necessary to assume the addition of water or some liquid substance, without its being mentioned in the text; as mere barley-grains cannot be drunk, until they are mixed up with a liquid substance.

In the second explanation, however, all that is necessary is to take the word тАШbarleyтАЩ in a figurative sense; and certainly, a figurative or indirect signification is much simpler than the assumption of what is not mentioned at all.

тАШHaving shaved his headтАЩтАФwith his hair shaved off; or it may simply mean with his hairs cut.

тАШCow-penтАЩтАФthe place where cows sit and rest.

тАШCovered with the skin of the cowтАЩтАФnot necessarily of the cow that has been killed; it may be of another cow also.тАФ(108)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

**(verses 11.108-116)
**

These verses are quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (Pr─Бya┼Ыcitta, p. 191), which adds that this refers to the ease of intentionally killing a cow belonging to a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa;тАФin Madanap─Бrij─Бta (p. 860), which notes that what is laid down in verses 108 to 113 refers to cases of intentional killing of a cow belonging to the Kс╣гatriya, and what is declared in verses 115 and 116 to cases of killing any cow belonging to a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa. It goes on to add the following notes:тАФSince the text mentions no other food, the man should live upon fruits and roots only; or the meaning may be that тАШanena vidhin─БтАЩ (of verse 115) refers to the two monthsтАЩ course detailed in the foregoing verses; and the sense is that the man who is unable to give ten cows with a bull should give away all his belongings. When however one unintentionally kills a cow, young and well-fed, belonging to a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa, he should observe the three-monthly penance prescribed by Aс╣Еgiras.

They are quoted also in Smс╣Ыtitattva (p. 519);тАФin Smс╣Ыtis─Бroddh─Бra (p. 358);тАФand in Pr─Бya┼Ыcittaviveka (pp. 196-197), which says that this refers to the ordinary killing of the cow, and not to its killing for sacrifices;тАФand adds the following explanation:тАФHe should shave his head, cover himself with the skin of the cow he has killed, and drink gruel of barley cooked in cowтАЩs urineтАЩ, and thus live in the cow-pen, for one month, and during the next two months he should fast during the day and eat a little in the evening,тАФтАШv─лr─БsanaтАЩ is sitting without any support,тАФтАШabhi┼ЫastaтАЩ attacked,тАФтАШbhayaihтАЩ by dangerous animals,тАФтАШsarvapr─Бс╣Зaiс╕етАЩ (which is its reading for sarvap─Бpaiс╕етАЩ), to the best of his powerтАФтАШg─Бm na kathayetтАЩ, with a view to have her driven away,тАФтАШsucaritavrataс╕етАЩ, he who has followed these restrictions in the right manner,тАФhe should give ten cows along with one bull.

Verse 115 only is quoted in the ┼Ъuddhikaumd─л (p.241).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 11.108-116)
**

Gautama (22.18).тАФтАШThe penance for killing a cow is the same as that for killing a Vai┼Ыya (vow of continence to be kept for three years and giving one cow and one bull).тАЩ

─Аpastamba (1.26, 1).тАФтАШIf a milch cow or a full-grown ox has been killed without reason, the expiation shall be the same as that for killing a ┼Ъ┼лdra (give ten cows with a bull).тАЩ

Va┼Ыiс╣гс╣нha (21.18).тАФтАШIf he kills a cow, he shall perform, during six months, a Kс╣Ыcchra or a Taptakс╣Ыcchra, clothed in the raw hide of that cow.тАЩ

Viс╣гс╣Зu (50, 16-24).тАФтАШThe man shall serve cows for a month, his hair and beard having been shaven;тАФhe shall sit down to rest when they rest; and stand still when they stand still;тАФhe shall give assistance to a cow that has met with an accident;тАФand shall preserve cows from dangers;тАФhe shall not shelter himself against cold and similar dangers, without having previously protected the cows against them;тАФhe shall wash himself with cowтАЩs urine; and subsist upon the five bovine products;тАФthis is the Go-vrata, cow-penance, which must be performed by one who has killed a cow.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (3.264-265).тАФтАШThe man who has killed a cow shall drink the five bovine products for a month, sleeping in the cowpen, serving the cows; and then by giving a cow, he becomes pure; or he shall calmly perform the penance of Pr─Бj─Бpatya Atikс╣Ыcchra;тАФor having fasted for three days, he shall give away ten cows with a hull as the eleventh.тАЩ

Par─Б┼Ыara (8.31-42).тАФтАШHaving shaved the whole head, he shall bathe three times during the day, and live among cows during the night, and go behind them during the day; when it is hot, or raining, or very cold or when the wind is blowing strongly, he shall not protect himself until he has protected the cows to the best of his ability. If he finds a cow grazing in a field or in a threshing yarnтАФeither his own or belonging to some one else,тАФhe shall not tell of it to any one; nor shall he tell any one when he finds a calf sucking milk. He shall drink water when the cows drink it, he down when they he down, and with all his strength shall save a cow when she has either fallen down or stuck in mud. One shall prescribe as penance for cow-killing a suitable Pr─Бj─Бpatya and Kс╣Ыcchra: (Forms of these penances)тАФFor one day he shall eat once; for one day he shall eat only in the evening; for one day he shall eat only what he gets without asking for it; and for one day he shall live on air; for two days he shall eat only once; for two days he shall eat what he gets without asking for it, for two days he shall eat only at night; for two days he shall live on air. Each of these being done for three days; and for four days. The prescribed penance having been performed, he shall feed Br─Бhmaс╣Зas, present them with fees and recite the sacred texts. After feeding the Br─Бhmaс╣Зas, the cow-killer becomes purified without doubt.тАЩ

B├╝hler

109 He who has committed a minor offence by slaying a cow (or bull) shall drink during (the first) month (a decoction of) barley-grains; having shaved all his hair, and covering himself with the hide (of the slain cow), he must live in a cow-house.

109 рдЪрддреБрд░реНрдердХрд╛рд▓рдореН рдЕрд╢реНрдиреАрдпрд╛рджреН ...{Loading}...

рдЪрддреБрд░реНрдердХрд╛рд▓рдореН рдЕрд╢реНрдиреАрдпрд╛рджреН
рдЕрдХреНрд╖рд╛рд░-рд▓рд╡рдгрдВ рдорд┐рддрдореН ред
рдЧреЛрдореВрддреНрд░реЗрдгрд╛рдЪрд░реЗрддреН рд╕реНрдирд╛рдирдВ
рджреНрд╡реМ рдорд╛рд╕реМ рдирд┐рдпрддреЗрдиреНрджреНрд░рд┐рдпрдГ рее резрез.резрежреп рее [резрежрео рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдкрд╛рдареЗ]

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

For two months, with senses controlled, he shall eat a limited quantity of food, without any pungent salt, at the fourth meal-time; and shall bathe in cowтАЩs urine.тАФ(109)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рджреНрд╡реМ рдорд╛рд╕рд╛рд╡реН рдПрдХреИрдХрдореН рдЖрд╣рд╛рд░рдВ рднреБрдХреНрддреНрд╡рд╛ рджреНрд╡рд┐рддреАрдпреЗ рд╜рд╣рдирд┐ рд╕рд╛рдпрдореН рдЕрд╢реНрдиреАрдпрд╛рддреН ред рд▓рд╡рдгрд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖реЗрдг рдХреНрд╖рд╛рд░рдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрд╛рддреН рд╕реИрдиреНрдзрд╡рд╕реНрдпрд╛рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реЗрдзрдГ ред рд╕реНрд╡рддрдиреНрддреНрд░рдГ рдХреНрд╖рд╛рд░рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реЗрдзреЛ рд╣рд┐ рджреНрд╡рдиреНрджреНрд╡реЗ рд╕рддрд┐ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН ред рддрддреНрд░ рд╡рдЪрдирдкреНрд░рд╡реГрддреНрддрд┐рдГ рдкрджрджреНрд╡рдпрд╕реНрдп рдЪ рд▓рдХреНрд╖рдгрд╛рд░реНрдерд╛ ред рдпреБрдЧрдкрджрдзрд┐рдХрд░рдгрддрд╛рдпрд╛рдВ рджреНрд╡рдиреНрджреНрд╡рдГ ред рд╕реНрдерд┐рддреЗ рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рдгрд╕рдорд╛рд╕реЗ рд╡рд┐рд╢рд┐рд╖реНрдЯрд╕реНрд╡реНрдпрд╛рд░реНрдерд╕реНрдп рдирд╛рдиреБрдЬреНрдЮрд╛рд╕рдВрдмрдиреНрдзрдГ ред рди рд╕рдорд╛рд╕рд╛рджрд┐рд▓рд╛рдШрд╡рдореН149 ред рдорд┐рддрдВ рд╕реНрд╡рд▓реНрдкрдореН рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрд░реНрдердГ ред рди рдпрд╛рд╡рддрд╛ рддреГрдкреНрддрд┐рд░реН рднрд╡рддрд┐ рд╢рд░реАрд░рд╕реНрдерд┐рддрд┐рд╢реН рдЪ рдЬрд╛рдпрддреЗ ред рдЧреЛрдореВрддреНрд░рд╕реНрдирд╛рдирдВ рддреНрд░рд┐рд╖реНрд╡реН рдЕрдкрд┐ рдХрд╛рд▓реЗрд╖реБ ред рдЪрддреБрд░реНрдердХрд╛рд▓рдВ рджреНрд╡реМ рдорд╛рд╕рд╛рд╡реН рдЗрддрд┐ рд╕рдВрдмрдиреНрдзрдГ ред рдПрд╡рдВ рд╕реНрдореГрддреНрдпрдиреНрддрд░реЗ-

  • рдХреГрддрд╡рдкрдиреЛ рд╡рд╕реЗрджреН рдЧреЛрд╖реНрдареЗ рдЪрд░реНрдордгрд╛ рддреЗрди рд╕рдВрд╡реГрддрдГ ред

  • рджреНрд╡реМ рдорд╛рд╕реМ рд╕реНрдирд╛рдирдореН рдЕрдкреНрдпреН рдЕрд╕реНрдп рдЧреЛрдореВрддреНрд░реЗрдг рд╡рд┐рдзреАрдпрддреЗ рее

  • рдкрд╛рджрд╢реМрдЪрдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рдХрд╛рд░реНрдпрдореН рдЕрджреНрднрд┐рдГ рдХреБрд░реНрд╡реАрдд рдХреЗрд╡рд▓рдореН рее

рди рдЪрд╛рд╕реНрдп рджреНрд╡реМ рдорд╛рд╕рд╛рд╡реН рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрдиреЗрди рд╕рдВрдмрдиреНрдзрдГ рд╕рдВрднрд╡рддрд┐ ред рд╕реНрдирд╛рдирдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрдВ рдкрд╛рджрдкреВрд░рдгрд╛рд░реНрдердореН ред рд╕реНрдирд╛рдирдХрд╛рд▓реЗ рдпрджрд┐ рдкрд╛рджрд╛рджреНрдпрд╢реБрджреНрдзрд┐рд░реН рднрд╡рддреНрдпреН рдЕрд░реНрдерд╛рддреН рддрджреБрджрдХреЗрдиреИрд╡ рджреНрд░рд╡реНрдпрд╢реБрджреНрдзрд┐рд╡рд┐рдзрд┐рдирд╛ рд╢реЛрдзрдиреАрдпрдореН ред рдЕрдд рдЖрдЪрдордирдореН рдЕрдкрд┐ рд╢реБрджреНрдзреНрдпрд░реНрдердореН рдЙрджрдХреЗрдиреИрд╡ рд╕реНрдирд╛рдирдХрд╛рд▓реЗ ред рдЕрдиреНрдпрджрд╛ рдореГрджрд╛ рд╢реБрджреНрдзрд┐рдГ ред рд╕рд╛ рдореГрджреНрд╡рд╛рд░рд┐рдХреНрд░рдореЗрдгреИрд╡ рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпрд╛ ред рд╕реНрдирд╛рдирд╡рд┐рдзреМ рдЧреЛрдореВрддреНрд░рд╢реНрд░рд╡рдгрд╛рджреН рдЖрдЪрдордирд╛рджреМ рдХрдГ рдкреНрд░рд╕рдЩреНрдЧрдГ ред рд╕реНрдирд╛рдиреЗ рд╜рдкрд┐ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдпрд╢реНрдЪрд┐рддреНрддрд╛рдЩреНрдЧреЗрди рд╢реБрджреНрдзреНрдпрд░реНрдердореН рее резрез.резрежреп рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШFor two monthsтАЩтАФhe shall take his food once and then again only in the evening of the next day.

If we take the term тАШKс╣г─БraтАЩтАФтАШpungentтАЩтАФas a qualification of тАШlavaс╣Зa,тАЩ тАШsalt,тАЩ we secure the prohibition of the rock-salt also. If the two terms were independent, the compound would be a copulative one, and this would mean the prohibition of тАШpungent substancesтАЩ also; and in that case it would be necessary to take the singular number as indirectly indicating the dual; as we have the copulative compound only, both the components are equally important at one and the same time. When however, the compound is taken as a тАШqualitativeтАЩ one (тАШpungentтАЩ being a qualification of the тАШsaltтАЩ), we obtain a qualified denotation.

тАШLimitedтАЩтАФsmall; i.e., that which, without producing full satisfaction, is enough to keep the body going.

тАШBathing in cowтАЩs urineтАЩ is to be done three times a day.

тАШAt the fourth meal-timeтАЩ is to be construed with тАШfor two months.тАЩ

In another Smс╣Ыti we readтАФтАШHaving shaved his head, covered with the skin, he shall live in the cow-pen; end bathing in cowтАЩs urine for two months has been prescribed for him; it is only the washing of the feet that he should do with water.тАЩ In this it is not possible to connect the bathing in cowтАЩs urine with the phrase тАШfor two months.тАЩ The mention of the feet is only for the purpose of filling up the metre; for, if any impurity happens to attach to the manтАЩs feet during the time that he is bathing, it would naturally be washed with water only; as is clearly laid down by the rules of purification. Hence at the time of bathing, the rinsing of the mouth also should he done with water; at other times purification may be secured by the use of clay and other cleansing substances; and this would have to be done in the natural orderтАФwater being used after clay has been applied. And since cowтАЩs urine has been prescribed for bathing only, what possibility would there be of its being used for the rinsing of the mouth or any such purpose? In connection with bathing, it is only as an expiation that the use of cowтАЩs urine has been prescribed.тАФ(109)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

**(verses 11.108-116)
**

See Explanatory notes for [Verse 11.108].

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 11.108-116)
**

See Comparative notes for [Verse 11.108].

B├╝hler

110 During the two (following) months he shall eat a small (quantity of food) without any factitious salt at every fourth meal-time, and shall bathe in the urine of cows, keeping his organs under control.

110 рджрд┐рд╡рд╛рдиреБрдЧрдЪреНрдЫреЗрджреН рдЧрд╛рд╕реН ...{Loading}...

рджрд┐рд╡рд╛рдиреБрдЧрдЪреНрдЫреЗрджреН рдЧрд╛рд╕реН рддрд╛рд╕реН рддреБ
рддрд┐рд╖реНрдардиреНрдиреН рдКрд░реНрдзреНрд╡рдВ рд░рдЬрдГ рдкрд┐рдмреЗрддреН ред
рд╢реБрд╢реНрд░реВрд╖рд┐рддреНрд╡рд╛ рдирдорд╕реНрдХреГрддреНрдп
рд░рд╛рддреНрд░реМ рд╡реАрд░рд╛рд╕рдирдВ рд╡рд╕реЗрддреН [рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдкрд╛рдардГ - рд╡реАрд░рд╛рд╕рдиреЛ] рее резрез.резрезреж рее [резрежреп рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдкрд╛рдареЗ]

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

During the day he shall follow those cows, and standing upright, inhale the dust; at night having attended and bowed to them, he shall rest in the тАШV─лr─БsanaтАЩ posture.тАФ(110)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдпрд╛рд╕рд╛рдВ рдЧрд╡рд╛рдВ рд╕реНрдерд╛рдиреЗ рд╡рд╕рддрд┐ рддрд╛рд╢реН рдЪрд░рд┐рддреБрдВ рдЧрдЪреНрдЫрдиреНрддреАрдГ рдкрд╢реНрдЪрд╛рджреН рдЧрдЪреНрдЫреЗрддреН ред рддрдЪреНрдЫрдмреНрджреЗрди рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрд╡рдорд░реНрд╢рд╛рджреН рдпрд╛рд╕рд╛рдВ рдЧреГрд╣реЗ рд╕реНрдерд┐рддрд╕реН рддрд╛рд╕рд╛рдореН ред рдЕрдиреНрдпрд╛рд╕рд╛рдВ рдЧрдЪреНрдЫрдиреНрддреАрдирд╛рдВ рди рднрд╡рддреНрдпреН рдЕрдиреБрдЧрдордирдореН ред рддрд╛рднрд┐рдГ рд╕рдореБрддреНрдерд╛рдкрд┐рддрдВ рд░рдЬреЛ рд░реЗрдгреБрд░реН рдКрд░реНрдзреНрд╡рдВ рдЧрдЪреНрдЫрдиреН рдкрд┐рдмреЗрддреН ред рдПрд╡рдВ рддрддреНрд░реИрд╡ рддрд╛рднрд┐рдГ рд╕рд╣ рджрд┐рд╡рд╕рдВ рд╡рд┐рд╣реГрддреНрдп рддрд╛рднрд┐рд░реН рдПрд╡ рд╕рд╣ рдкреБрдирд░реН рдЧреЛрд╖реНрдардореН рдЖрдЧрдЪреНрдЫреЗрддреН ред рд╢реБрд╢реНрд░реВрд╖рдпрд┐рддреНрд╡рд╛ рдХрдгреНрдбреВрдХрд░реНрд╖рдгрд░рдЬреЛрдкрдиреЛрджрдиреЗрдиреЛрдкрдЧрдЪреНрдЫрдиреН ред рдирдорд╕реНрдХреГрддреНрдп рдЬрд╛рдиреБрд╢рд┐рд░рд╕рд╛ рдкреНрд░рдгрд╛рдордВ рдХреГрддреНрд╡рд╛ ред рд╡реАрд░рд╛рд╕рдиреЛ рд╡рд╕реЗрддреН ред рднрд┐рддреНрддрд┐рд╢рдпреНрдпрд╛рджрд╛рд╡реН рдЕрдирд┐рд╖рджреНрдп рдпрджреН рдЙрдкрд╡рд┐рд╖реНрдЯрд╕реНрдпрд╛рд╡рд╕реНрдерд╛рдирдВ рддрджреН рд╡реАрд░рд╛рд╕рдирдореН рее резрез.резрезреж рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

When he is living in a cow-pen, he shall follow the cows that live in that pen, when they go out to graze. The use of the pronoun тАШthoseтАЩ implies that he should follow those cows in whose pen he is living; specially as, if he were to go after other cows, this would not mean constant тАШfollowing.тАЩ

And while going along he shall inhale the dust raised by the cows.

Having wandered about with the cows, during the day, he should return to the pen with them.

Having тАШattended to themтАЩтАФserved them by rubbing their bodies and removed the dust from them; and тАШhaving bowed to themтАЩтАФkneeling, and with his head down;тАФтАШhe shall rest in the V─лr─Бsana posture.тАЩ When one rests, neither on a raised platform nor on a bedstead, but simply by sitting down, it is called the тАШV─лr─БsanaтАЩ posture.тАФ(110)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

**(verses 11.108-116)
**

See Explanatory notes for [Verse 11.108].

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 11.108-116)
**

See Comparative notes for [Verse 11.108].

B├╝hler

111 During the day he shall follow the cows and, standing upright, inhale the dust (raised by their hoofs); at night, after serving and worshipping them, he shall remain in the (posture, called) virasana.

111 рддрд┐рд╖реНрдардиреНрддреАрд╖реНрд╡реН рдЕрдиреБрддрд┐рд╖реНрдареЗрддреН ...{Loading}...

рддрд┐рд╖реНрдардиреНрддреАрд╖реНрд╡реН рдЕрдиреБрддрд┐рд╖реНрдареЗрддреН рддреБ
рд╡реНрд░рдЬрдиреНрддреАрд╖реНрд╡реН рдЕрдкреНрдпреН рдЕрдиреБрд╡реНрд░рдЬреЗрддреН ред
рдЖрд╕реАрдирд╛рд╕реБ рддрдерд╛рд╕реАрдиреЛ
рдирд┐рдпрддреЛ рд╡реАрдд-рдорддреНрд╕рд░рдГ рее резрез.резрезрез рее [резрезреж рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдкрд╛рдареЗ]

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

Self-controlled and free from greed, he shall stand when they stand, follow them when they move, and sit when they have sat down.тАФ(111)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рддрд┐рд╖реНрдардиреНрддреАрддреНрдпреН рдПрд╡рдорд╛рджрд┐рдХреЛ рд╡рд┐рдзрд┐рдГ ред рдпрддреНрд░ рдХрд╛рд╢реНрдЪрд┐рддреН рддрд┐рд╖реНрдардиреНрддрд┐ рдХрд╛рд╢реНрдЪрд┐рджреН рд╡реНрд░рдЬрдиреНрддрд┐ рдХрд╛рд╢реНрдЪрд┐рджреН рд╡рд╛рд╕рддреЗ, рддрддреНрд░ рднреВрдпрд╕реАрдирд╛рдВ рдзрд░реНрдордВ рд╕рдорд╛рд╢реНрд░рдпреЗрддреН ред рд╡реАрддреЛ рдорддреНрд╕рд░реЛ рд▓реЛрднреЛ рдпрд╕реНрдпреЗрддрд┐ ред рдкреНрд░рджрд░реНрд╢рдирд╛рд░реНрдердВ рдЪреИрддрддреН ред рддреНрдпрдХреНрддрд░рд╛рдЧрд╛рджрд┐рдордиреЛрджреЛрд╖ рдЗрддрд┐ рдпрд╛рд╡рддреН, рдирд┐рдпрддреЗрдиреНрджреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╡рдЪрдирд╛рддреН (рдореНрдзреН резрез.резрежреп) рее резрез.резрезрез рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШHe shall standтАЩ etc., is an Injunction.

When some cows are standing, some are walking and some are sitting, he shall do what most of them are doing.

тАШFree from greedтАЩтАФcoveting nothing. This is only by way of illustration; the meaning is that he shall be free from all such mental aberrations as love, hatred and the like. That this is so is shown by the epithet тАШself-controlledтАЩ.тАФ(111)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

**(verses 11.108-116)
**

See Explanatory notes for [Verse 11.108].

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 11.108-116)
**

See Comparative notes for [Verse 11.108].

B├╝hler

112 Controlling himself and free from anger, he must stand when they stand, follow them when they walk, and seat himself when they lie down.

112 рдЖрддреБрд░рд╛рдореН рдЕрднрд┐рд╢рд╕реНрддрд╛рдореН ...{Loading}...

рдЖрддреБрд░рд╛рдореН рдЕрднрд┐рд╢рд╕реНрддрд╛рдВ рд╡рд╛
рдЪреМрд░-рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдШреНрд░рд╛рджрд┐рднрд┐рд░реН рднрдпреИрдГ ред
рдкрддрд┐рддрд╛рдВ рдкрдЩреНрдХрд▓рдЧреНрдирдВ рд╡рд╛
рд╕рд░реНрд╡реЛрдкрд╛рдпреИрд░реН рд╡рд┐рдореЛрдЪрдпреЗрддреН [рдХреН:рд╕рд░реНрд╡рдкреНрд░рд╛рдгреИрд░реН] рее резрез.резрезреи рее [резрезрез рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдкрд╛рдареЗ]

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

When a cow is sick, or threatened with danger from thieves, tigers and the like, or falls, or becomes stuck in a morass, he shall rescue her with all his strength.тАФ(112)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдЖрддреБрд░рд╛рдВ рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдзрд┐рддрд╛рдореН ред рдЕрднрд┐рд╢рд╕реНрддрд╛рдВ рдЧреГрд╣рд┐рддрд╛рдореН150 ред рднрдпреИрд░реН рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдШреНрд░рд╛рджрд┐рдирд┐рдорд┐рддреНрддреИрдГ ред рд╕рд░реНрд╡реЗрдг рд╕рд╛рдорд░реНрдереНрдпреЗрди рдкреНрд░рд╛рдгрд╢рдмреНрджреЛрдЪреНрдЫреНрд╡рд╛рд╕рдкрд╡рди151 рдПрд╡, рдЕрд▓рдкрдкреНрд░рд╛рдгреИрд░реН рдорд╣рд╛рдкреНрд░рд╛рдг рдЗрддрд┐ рд╕реНрдереВрд▓реЗ рдмрд▓рд╡рддрд┐ рдЪ рдкреНрд░рдпреЛрдЧрджрд░реНрд╢рдирд╛рддреН ред рддреЗрди рд╕реНрд╡рдпрдореН рдЕрд╢рдХреНрддреЗрди рд╕рд╣рд╛рдпрдХреЛрдкрд╛рджрд╛рдиреЗрдирд╛рдкреНрдпреН рдЙрджреНрдзрд╛рд░рдГ рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпрдГ рее резрез.резрезреи рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШSickтАЩтАФsuffering from a disease.

тАШThreatenedтАЩтАФcaught upтАФтАШby dangerтАЩ proceeding тАШfrom thieves, tigers and the like.тАЩ

тАШSarvapr─Бс╣Зaiс╕етАЩтАФwith all his strength. The word тАШpr─Бс╣ЗaтАЩ does not always mean the life-breath; as we find such expressions тАШalpapr─Бс╣ЗaтАЩ and тАШmah─Бpr─Бс╣ЗaтАЩ in the sense of weak and strong respectively. Thus, when he is unable, by himself, to rescue her, he should bring about bur rescue with the help of other men.тАФ(112)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

**(verses 11.108-116)
**

See Explanatory notes for [Verse 11.108].

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

**(verses 11.108-116)
**

See Comparative notes for [Verse 11.108].

B├╝hler

113 (When a cow is) sick, or is threatened by danger from thieves, tigers, and the like, or falls, or sticks in a morass, he must relieve her by all possible means:

113 рдЙрд╖реНрдгреЗ рд╡рд░реНрд╖рддрд┐ ...{Loading}...

рдЙрд╖реНрдгреЗ рд╡рд░реНрд╖рддрд┐ рд╢реАрддреЗ рд╡рд╛
рдорд╛рд░реБрддреЗ рд╡рд╛рддрд┐ рд╡рд╛ рднреГрд╢рдореН ред
рди рдХреБрд░реНрд╡реАрддрд╛рддреНрдордирд╕реН рддреНрд░рд╛рдгрдВ
рдЧреЛрд░реН рдЕрдХреГрддреНрд╡рд╛ рддреБ рд╢рдХреНрддрд┐рддрдГ рее резрез.резрезрей рее [резрезреи рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдкрд╛рдареЗ]

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

In heat, in rain, in cold, or when the wind is blowing violently, he shall not shelter himself, without having sheltered the cows to the best of his ability.тАФ(113)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдЙрд╖реНрдгреЗрди рднреГрд╢рдВ рддрдкрддреНрдпреН рдЖрджрд┐рддреНрдпреЗ рд╡рд░реНрд╖рддрд┐ рдкрд░реНрдЬрдиреНрдпреЗ рд╢реАрддреЗ рд╡рд╛ рдорд╛рд░реБрддреЗ рд╡рд╛рддрд┐ рд╡рд╛рдпреМ рднреГрд╢рдореН рдЗрддрд┐ рее резрез.резрезрей рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШIn heatтАЩтАФwhen the sun is very strong.

тАШIn rainтАЩтАФwhen the clouds are pouring down rain.

тАШIn cold and when the wind is blowing violently.тАЩ

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

B├╝hler

114 In heat, in rain, or in cold, or when the wind blows violently, he must not seek to shelter himself, without (first) sheltering the cows according to his ability.

114 рдЖрддреНрдордиреЛ рдпрджрд┐ ...{Loading}...

рдЖрддреНрдордиреЛ рдпрджрд┐ рд╡рд╛рдиреНрдпреЗрд╖рд╛рдВ
рдЧреГрд╣реЗ рдХреНрд╖реЗрддреНрд░реЗ рд╜рде рд╡рд╛ рдЦрд▓реЗ ред
рднрдХреНрд╖рдпрдиреНрддреАрдВ рди рдХрдердпреЗрддреН
рдкрд┐рдмрдиреНрддрдВ рдЪреИрд╡ рд╡рддреНрд╕рдХрдореН рее резрез.резрезрек рее [резрезрей рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдкрд╛рдареЗ]

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

If the cow is eating anything in his own or anotherтАЩs house, field or threshing-yard,тАФor when her calf is drinking (her milk),тАФhe shall not say anything.тАФ(114)

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рд╡реНрд░реАрд╣реНрдпрд╛рджрд┐рднрдХреНрд╖рдпрдиреНрддреАрдВ рдЧрд╛рдВ рди рд╡рд╛рд░рдпреЗрддреН152 ред рди рдЪрд╛рдиреНрдпрд╛рдиреН рдЖрдЪрдХреНрд╖реАрдд рдирд┐рд╡рд╛рд░рдгрд╛рд░реНрдердореН ред рдпрджрд┐ рддреБ рдмрдзреНрдиреАрдпрддреН рдЖрд╢рдЩреНрдХреНрдпрддреЗ рдмрд╛рдз рдЗрддрд┐ рддреГрдкреНрддреНрдпрд╛ рддрджрд╛ рдкреВрд░реНрд╡реЛрдХреНрддрдХрд░рдгреЗ рди рджреЛрд╖рдГ ред рддрджрдиреБрдЧреНрд░рд╣реЛ рд╡рд┐рдзреАрдпрддреЗ ред рдПрд╡рдВ рдкрд┐рдмрдиреНрддрдВ рд╡рддреНрд╕рдХрдореН рдЕрдкрд┐ рее резрез.резрезрек рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

He shall not prevent the cow from eating anything in the shape of corns, etc.; nor shall he tell anyone else with a view to lead him to prevent her. If, however, he ties her up for fear of danger that might befall her otherwise,тАФor after she has become satisfied,тАФthere is no harm; it is, on the contrary, a favour.

Similarly he shall not prevent her calf from drinking her milk.тАФ(114)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

**

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

B├╝hler

115 Let him not say (a word), if a cow eats (anything) in his own or another’s house or field or on the threshing-floor, or if a calf drinks (milk).

рдЕрдиреЗрди рд╡рд┐рдзрд┐рдирд╛ рдпрд╕реН рддреБ
рдЧреЛрдШреНрдиреЛ рдЧрд╛рдореН рдЕрдиреБрдЧрдЪреНрдЫрддрд┐ ред
рд╕ рдЧреЛрд╣рддреНрдпрд╛рдХреГрддрдВ рдкрд╛рдкрдВ
